Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 384, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 586, 598, 601]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 601, 606, 616]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 609, 646]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 646, 756, 661]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 661, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 662, 92]]<|/det|>
On average, 1 clover plant in 10 000 has four leaves instead of three.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 104, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 104, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Use an approximating distribution to calculate the probability that, in a random sample of 2000 clover plants, more than 2 will have four leaves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 688, 186, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 688, 477, 707]]<|/det|>
Justify your approximating distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 689, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
Past experience has shown that the heights of a certain variety of plant have mean \(64.0 \text{cm}\) and standard deviation \(3.8 \text{cm}\). During a particularly hot summer, it was expected that the heights of plants of this variety would be less than usual. In order to test whether this was the case, a botanist recorded the heights of a random sample of 100 plants and found that the value of the sample mean was \(63.3 \text{cm}\). Stating a necessary assumption, carry out the test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The waiting time at a certain bus stop has variance 2.6 minutes \(^2\). For a random sample of 75 people, the mean waiting time was 7.1 minutes. Calculate a \(92\%\) confidence interval for the population mean waiting time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A researcher used 3 random samples to calculate 3 independent \(92\%\) confidence intervals. Find the probability that all 3 of these confidence intervals contain only values that are greater than the actual population mean.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 611, 176, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 608, 920, 658]]<|/det|>
Another researcher surveyed the first 75 people who waited at a bus stop on a Monday morning. Give a reason why this sample is unsuitable for use in finding a confidence interval for the mean waiting time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 640, 920, 658]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 83, 707, 235]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 255, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
The time, \(X\) minutes, taken by a large number of runners to complete a certain race has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 288, 611, 349]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{k}{x^2} & 5\leqslant x\leqslant 10,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 349, 495, 368]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant, as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 380, 156, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 380, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
Without calculation, explain how you can tell that there were more runners whose times were below 7.5 minutes than above 7.5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 399, 920, 416]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 637, 156, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 637, 301, 655]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = 10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 638, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Large packets of sugar are packed in cartons, each containing 12 packets. The weights of these packets are normally distributed with mean \(505 \mathrm{~g}\) and standard deviation \(3.2 \mathrm{~g}\). The weights of the cartons, when empty, are independently normally distributed with mean \(150 \mathrm{~g}\) and standard deviation \(7 \mathrm{~g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 151, 153, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 151, 759, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total weight of a full carton is less than \(6200 \mathrm{~g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Small packets of sugar are packed in boxes. The total weight of a full box has a normal distribution with mean \(3130 \text{g}\) and standard deviation \(12.1 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 120, 154, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the weight of a randomly chosen full carton is less than double the weight of a randomly chosen full box.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
The number of sports injuries per month at a certain college has a Poisson distribution. In the past the mean has been 1.1 injuries per month. The principal recently introduced new safety guidelines and she decides to test, at the \(2\%\) significance level, whether the mean number of sports injuries has been reduced. She notes the number of sports injuries during a 6-month period.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 152, 154, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 151, 769, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the critical region for the test and state the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
